Enhancement of diethyl malonate hydrogenation to 1,3-propanediol using mesoporous Cu/SBA-15 as catalyst Jintao Yu Jingshun Cao Lihui Du Yongmei Wei Tao Wang Hengshui Tian ⁎ School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China School of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract SBA-15 is considered as an ideal support to ensure a copper-based catalyst with high activity and selectivity. In this work, the hydrogenation of diethyl malonate (DEM) to 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO) over Cu/SBA-15 catalysts was investigated. Compared to the conventional Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts exhibited higher DEM conversions (up to 95%), better 1,3-PDO selectivities (up to 61%), and longer lifetime (over 180 h). These improvements were ascribed to the well-ordered tubular channel structure, better copper active-site dispersion, and appropriate Cu+/Cu° ratio in the Cu/SBA-15, affording higher TOFs and copper species surface areas, which was confirmed by N2-physisorption, X-ray diffraction, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy, N2O titration, transmission electron microscopy, H2 temperature-programmed reduction, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyses. The Cu/SBA-15 in this work advances the prospects of DEM hydrogenation as a promising method to produce 1,3-PDO on industrial scale. Keywords Hydrogenation SBA-15 1,3-Propanediol Copper-based catalyst 1 Introduction 1,3-Propanediol (1,3-PDO) is a crucial industrial chemical that finds wide-ranging application in materials as varied as dry-set mortars, resins, water-based inks, and engine coolants [1]. Among these applications, the vast majority of 1,3-PDO is used to manufacture polytrimethylene terephthalate (PTT), a polyester which shows many excellent properties including superior stretchability, lower dyeing temperature, wider color range accommodation, and greater stain resistance [2,3]. To date, the main commercial processes for the production of 1,3-PDO include two chemical methods (Degussa and Shell processes) and a bio-fermentation method (DuPont) [4]. Both the Degussa and Shell processes [5–7] suffer from disadvantages such as high pressures (10 MPa), high costs, toxic cobalt-based catalysts, and serious environmental pollution. More importantly, a number of aldehyde side products are produced by these chemical methods, lowering the production quality below the desirable polymer- and fiber-grade levels (99.9 wt%) [1]. Bio-fermentation technology has also been developed to produce 1,3-PDO through glucose or glycerol conversion [8,9]. Although the bio-fermentation method can produce one-tenth of the aldehyde impurities (0.003 wt%) in the 1,3-PDO compared to the chemical methods, its low yield and complex separation steps remain serious drawbacks [1]. Therefore, the development of an alternative or novel approach to overcome the problems of the chemical and bio-fermentation methods remains necessary. Currently, an alternative method involving the green hydrogenation of esters using a copper-based catalyst to produce 1,3-PDO has received considerable attention [10–12]. Specifically, this process involves the initial hydrogenation of diethyl malonate (DEM) to form ethyl 3-hydroxypropanoate (HPE), followed by the hydrogenation of HPE to generate 1,3-PDO. DEM is a green and safe chemical feedstock that has been synthetized from syngas or by biomass methods on commercial scale. Compared to the conventional processes, the DEM hydrogenation method usually proceeds under mild reaction conditions. In particular, no aldehydes are contained in the 1,3-PDO product. In addition, the low-cost, non-toxic, copper-based catalysts can selectively activate carbon-oxygen bonds, and thus, have been widely utilized in ester hydrogenation processes (such as dimethyl oxalate (DMO) and diethyl oxalate (DEO)) [13,14], which would make the DEM hydrogenation method a cost-competitive and environmentally friendly process for the production of 1,3-PDO. Nevertheless, the selectivity for 1,3-PDO and lifetime of the copper-based catalyst are still great challenges for DEM hydrogenation before large-scale use [12]. Concerning these problems, previous studies on Cu/SiO2 catalysts suggested that the calcination temperature, metal loading, and promoter metal play important roles in the selectivity for 1,3-PDO and catalyst lifetime. For example, Ding et al. investigated the effect of the calcination temperature on the transformation of copper species in a DEM hydrogenation process, resulting in a DEM conversion of 90.7% and 1,3-PDO selectivity of 32.3% [10]. Zheng et al. studied metal loading in a dimethyl malonate (DMM) hydrogenation process, achieving a 1,3-PDO yield as high as 41.7% [12]. From these studies, the amorphous Cu/SiO2 catalyst was found to show unsatisfactory selectivity for 1,3-PDO. Furthermore, the Cu/SiO2 catalyst had a relatively low specific surface area (∼350 m2/g), and the low melting point of the copper metal could easily lead to sintering deactivation, thus reducing the catalyst lifetime. Therefore, it is still a challenge to develop or design copper-based catalysts with higher selectivity for 1,3-PDO and longer lifetimes for the ester hydrogenation process. Generally, two major strategies can be employed to modify the copper-based catalyst. The first involves the promoter metal. For example, Cu-Cr, Cu-Ni, Cu-Ag, and Cu-Au bimetal catalysts using amorphous silicate as the support can form intermetallic or alloy phases with synergistic effects, which can be resistant to copper sintering and contribute to better catalytic performance in the ester hydrogenation process [15–18]. According to previous reports, the addition of a small amount of noble metal enabled full DMO conversion with over 95% ethylene glycol (EG) selectivity, and the modified catalyst remained active over 150 h [16,17]. Unfortunately, some bimetal-site catalysts exhibited better catalytic performance for ester hydrogenation only under lower liquid hourly space velocities (LHSV) (0.2 h−1) and higher H2/ester molar ratios (100 mol/mol). Furthermore, noble or toxic metals inevitably face higher cost, safety, and environmental challenges. As another strategy, mesoporous silicate materials as supports have been considered to hold promise for enhancing the quality of copper-based catalysts. Specifically, the mesoporous silicate families, including HMS, M41S, and SBA-n, possess regular hexagonal mesostructures and huge specific surface areas (over 700 m2/g), allowing their wide application as adsorbents [19,20], carrier materials [21], and catalysts [22–26]. Typically, when used as supports, these materials provide a means to eliminate internal diffusion and improve the metal dispersion in heterogeneous catalysis [27]. In the ester hydrogenation process, Cu/HMS, Cu/MCM-41, and Cu/SBA-15 catalysts have been found to exhibit better activities and more stable catalytic performance. For example, the HMS-support catalyst reported by Yin et al. achieved 100% ester conversion and 92% EG selectivity in the DMO hydrogenation process [28]. In Ma et al.’s study, the Cu/MCM-41 catalyst produced a 92% yield of EG with a lifetime of over 100 h even at an LHSV as high as 3.0 h−1 [29]. For the SBA-15-supported catalyst, in particular, it was found that even at a copper loading of 50 wt%, the copper particle size remained at 22 nm, while the copper species were simultaneously highly dispersed [30]. Besides, a 66.1% yield of 1,4-BDO was achieved using Cu/SBA-15 as catalyst in the dimethyl maleate hydrogenation process, which was much higher activity compared to the conventional catalysts [31]. Among the mesoporous silicates, SBA-15 is considered as a promising support; synthesized using a recyclable surfactant template, SBA-15 possesses a high surface area (700–1000 m2/g), tunable channel size (3–30 nm), and unique framework with a well-defined pore arrangement [32]. In fact, when used as a support, SBA-15, exhibits higher thermal and hydrothermal stabilities, as well as better catalyst reusability [33,34]. Owing to these advantages over HMS and MCM-41, SBA-15 would be expected to enhance copper-based catalyst activity and selectivity, and prolong the lifetime of the catalyst in the DEM hydrogenation process. Furthermore, the SBA-15 support with its tunable tubular framework structure should be suitable for probing structure-activity relationships. However, to the best of our knowledge, very few studies have focused on copper-based catalysts using the mesoporous silicate SBA-15 support in the DEM hydrogenation process. Thus, there may be enormous potential in using SBA-15 as a support to overcome the unsatisfactory selectivity for 1,3-PDO and the poor stability of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst in the DEM hydrogenation process. Therefore, in the present work, Cu/SBA-15 catalysts with extremely large specific surface areas and well-dispersed active sites on the ordered silicate framework were synthesized by the ammonia evaporation method. Subsequently, the effects of the pressure, temperature, H2/ester ratio, and LHSV on the DEM hydrogenation process over the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts were investigated. In particular, the lifetimes of the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts in the DEM hydrogenation were assessed. To fully characterize and understand the structure-activity performance of the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts, N2-physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), N2O titration, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation SBA-15: Mesoporous SBA-15 with a tubular channel structure was synthesized according to Zhao et al. [32]. Tri-block polymer P123 (12.08 g, EO20PO70EO20, M av = 5800; Aldrich), deionized H2O (311 mL), and HCl (60 mL, 36–38%, Adamas-Beta) were mixed in a flask for 4 h. Next, tetraethyl orthosilicate (25.6 g, TEOS, >98%, Adamas-Beta) was added dropwise into the solution and aged for 24 h. Then, the mixture was transferred into a PTFE container and hydrothermally treated for 72 h. After filtration and washing with deionized water and ethanol, the obtained powder was heated at 823 K for 5 h. Cu/SBA-15: An appropriate amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (>99%; Sinopharm Chemical) was dissolved in deionized water (100 mL) to afford a copper loading of 10, 15, 20, or 25 wt% with respect to the SBA-15 powder. Aqueous ammonia (25 wt%) was added to adjust the pH to 11.0. Then, SBA-15 powder (6.4 g) was added into the solution and stirred for 4 h. Thereafter, the mixture was heated to 363 K to evaporate the ammonia until pH value was 7.5. After filtration and washing with deionized water and ethanol, the obtained solid was dried in an oven at 373 K for 12 h and calcined at 723 K for 4 h. The different copper-loaded samples were labelled as xCu/SBA-15, where x represents the loading amount (wt%). 2.2 Catalyst characterization Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Agilent 725ES) was used to analyze the actual copper contents. Before the analysis, samples were dissolved in HF, and then diluted with water. FT-IR was conducted using a Nicolet 5700 instrument equipped with a KBr beam splitter at a resolution of 2 cm−1. Each sample was mixed with KBr and pressed into a self-supported wafer, placed into a sample holder and scanned 32 times in the 400–4000 cm−1 range. N2O titration, in which surface copper atoms are oxidized through the reaction 2Cu(s) + N2O → Cu2O(s) + N2, was conducted with a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920. The calcined catalysts were first reduced under a 10% H2/Ar flow for 1.5 h at 573 K. After cooling to 323 K under Ar flow, a flow of 10% N2O/He was introduced at a rate of 50 mL/min to oxidize the surface copper atoms to Cu2O. The content of Cu2O was then determined through a H2 reduction process at 623 K under 10% H2/Ar flow. The copper atom’s surface area and dispersion of Cu were determined by H2 consumption, and 1.46 × 1019 copper atoms per square meter were assumed [35]. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the calcined catalysts were obtained at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP2020 instrument. Vacuum degassing was first conducted at 423 K for 1 h. The specific surface area (A BET) was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Pore volumes (VP ) were derived from the adsorbed N2 volume at a relative pressure of 0.99. Pore volume distributions were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. XRD profiles were obtained with a Bruker D8 FOCUS diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation in a scanning angle range of 10–80° at a scan rate of 2°/min. The working voltage and current were 40 kV and 100 mA, respectively. The Cu crystallite size d C u ( n m ) was calculated based on the Scherrer equation: d C u n m = k λ β c o s θ where k is 0.9 for spherical particles, λ X-ray wavelength (0.15418 nm), and β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of reduced samples peaks (2θ = 43.5° for Cu(111)) in XRD [36]. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted with a Micromeritics Autochem II ASAP 2090. The calcined catalyst powder (50 mg) was treated under N2 flow at 473 K for 1 h. After cooling to 303 K, the inline gas was changed to 10% H2/N2 and the powder was heated at a rate of 10 K/min to 723 K, where it was maintained for 30 min. The hydrogen consumption was determined with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). TEM was carried out using a JEOL JEM-2100 equipped with a Gatan-832 CCD camera system and Genesis XM2 energy spectrum system, at a working voltage of 200 kV. Before the analysis, samples were ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol at room temperature for 15 min and deposited on copper grids coated with amorphous carbon films. XPS was performed with an ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher), equipped with an Al Kα anode (E = 1486.6 eV) and a working voltage of 100 eV. The binding energies were calibrated against adventitious carbon contaminants (C 1s = 284.8 eV). Before measurement, the catalyst powders were activated with H2 (100 mL/min) at 573 K for 4 h and collected under N2 protection. 2.3 Catalytic testing DEM hydrogenation was performed using a tubular fixed-bed microreactor with a 10-mm inside diameter. For a typical hydrogenation reaction, the catalyst precursor (5 mL) was first placed in the constant-temperature zone, and then quartz powder was packed on both sides of the fixed bed to ensure a plug flow profile. A thermocouple was inserted into the catalyst zone to measure temperature. Prior to the hydrogenation reaction, the catalyst precursor was activated using H2 (100 mL/min, purity >99.9%) at 573 K for 4 h under atmospheric pressure. Next, DEM was dissolved in ethanol (7.5 wt%) and pumped into the preheater. The outlet products were collected after reaching the steady state (after 5 h). Each sample was analyzed 3 times with a relative standard deviation (RSD) of less than 3% by gas chromatography (model GC9800; 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm HP-5 capillary column, Agilent) with FID using the internal standard method. The reproducibility of the experiments and their material balances was tested three times, as shown in Tables S1–S3. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface chemical species The FT-IR spectra of the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts with different copper loadings are presented in Fig. 1 . All samples clearly show the stretching and bending vibrations of OH groups due to adsorbed water at 3464 and 1634 cm−1, respectively. The adsorption bands due to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of SiOSi bonds are visible at 1107 and 805 cm−1, respectively. Peaks at 459, 970, and 665 cm−1 become broader and more intense compared with the plain SBA-15 support, which is evidence for the introduction of the copper species into the SBA-15 framework. The peak at 665 cm−1 is characteristic for the copper phyllosilicate structure [37,38]. The relatively sharp and distinct peak at 459 cm−1 due to SiOSi in the pristine SBA-15 support broadens and intensifies after copper introduction. This may be related to the characteristic peak frequencies of the CuO bond located near 575, 500, and 460 cm−1; the latter is close to 459 cm−1. We speculate that the more intense, broader peak at 459 cm−1 results from the CuO structure. Similar conclusions have been reported elsewhere [29,39]. The peak at 970 cm−1 in the SBA-15 support without copper is more reasonably ascribed to the Si–O stretching vibration of silanol (SiOH) groups, because no copper species are added. After the introduction of copper, owing to the formation of new SiOCu bonds, this peak broadens and is enveloped in the large SiO framework peak [40]. Therefore, after the copper species are introduced into the SBA-15, the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts exhibit broader and more intense peaks at 459, 970, and 665 cm−1, which indicates that the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts possess copper phyllosilicate and CuO structures. These results are comparable to those previously reported for the Cu/SiO2 catalyst [13,35]. The copper phyllosilicate content could be estimated according to the I665/I805 value [37], as shown in Table 1 . Clearly, the copper phyllosilicate content increases with increasing copper loading, suggesting stronger metal-support interactions between the Cu and SBA-15. As reported by Zheng et al. [41], the migration and aggregation of the copper species on the support are the main reasons for the deactivation of the copper-based catalyst. However, the strong metal-support interactions between Cu and SBA-15 are considered beneficial toward prolonging the lifetime of the Cu/SBA-15 catalyst. Fig. 2 presents the XRD patterns of all the calcined and reduced samples. For the Cu/SBA-15 samples, relatively smooth curves are evident in both Fig. 2A and B, which suggests that the copper species retain a small particle size and are well dispersed, according to Scherrer equation. In Fig. 2A, the peaks at 31.0°, 34.8°, 57.2°, and 63.3° correspond to copper phyllosilicate (JCPDS 00-003-0219), which is also confirmed by the foregoing FT-IR data. However, after reduction (Fig. 2B), only the 15Cu/SiO2 sample (a) exhibits distinct peaks at 37° and 44.3°, which indicates a larger particle size of 26.4 nm (see Table 1) formed during reduction of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. This difference between the Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/SiO2 samples is ascribed to the good dispersion of the copper species on the regular structure of the SBA-15, which can limit copper particle growth during both the calcination and reduction processes. As the copper content increases in the Cu/SBA-15 samples, the intensive peaks can be seen at 37° and 44.3°. This indicates that the increasing copper content on the SBA-15 results in the growth of copper species’ particle size from 10.2 nm for the 10Cu/SBA-15 to 18.4 nm for the 25Cu/SBA-15 (Table 1). Furthermore, the two peaks at 37° and 44.3° represent the copper species Cu2O (JCPDS 05-0667) and metallic copper (Cu°, JCPDS 04-0836), respectively. Generally, the copper species are well dispersed in the forms of copper phyllosilicate and CuO on the Cu/SBA-15 samples. The coexistence of Cu2O and metallic copper formed after reduction should improve the activity and stability of the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts. 3.2 Textural structure To investigate the textural structure of the Cu/SBA-15 catalyst with different copper loadings, the TEM images of all the samples were obtained and are shown in Fig. 3 . The 15Cu/SiO2 sample (Fig. 3a) presents a lamellar shape corresponding to its amorphous morphology. In contrast, the SBA-15 exhibits a regular tubular channel structure (Fig. 3b); this structure is believed to increase the activity and stability of the catalyst in ester hydrogenation processes [31,42]. When the copper species are introduced into the support, the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts present the same textural structure as the SBA-15 at a low loading (Fig. 3c and d). As the copper content increases, however, the catalysts gradually become more irregular than the initial tubular channel structure, as shown in Fig. 3e and f. In fact, a high copper loading can lead to excessive copper deposition on the support, partially collapsing or blocking the SBA-15 framework, which is unfavorable for the activity and stability of the copper-based catalyst. In addition, the irregular structures in the 20Cu/SBA-15 and 25Cu/SBA-15 samples show more whisker-shaped copper phyllosilicates present on the sample edges, which is also confirmed by the FT-IR results. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves, pore diameter distributions, and small-angle XRD patterns were further determined to study the mesoporous structures of the samples (Fig. 4 ). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves are revealed as Langmuir type-IV isotherms with H1-type hysteresis loops (Fig. 4A), indicating a typical large-pore mesoporous structure. The rapid increases in all the curves indicate the capillary condensation of nitrogen with uniform mesoporous size [43]. Specifically, in Fig. 4B, the 15Cu/SiO2 sample presents a wider bimodal pore size distribution due to its amorphous morphology. However, the SBA-15 support sample exhibits a single distinct peak and narrow pore size distribution, which indicates a regular tubular channel structure with an average pore diameter of 8.4 nm (Table 1), well consistent with its TEM image. Furthermore, both the 10Cu/SBA-15 and 15Cu/SBA-15 samples maintain a well-ordered mesoporous structure like the SBA-15 support, with average pore diameters of 8.1 and 8.0 nm (Table 1), respectively. As the copper loading increases to 20%, the channel diameters of 20Cu/SBA-15 and 25Cu/SBA-15 catalysts decrease from 8.4 to 6.7 nm (Table 1), respectively, and the bimodal distribution of the pore sizes indicates their blocked and partially collapsed channels. All these observations are in good agreement with the TEM results. In addition, the small-angle XRDs in Fig. 4C also confirm the pore structure changes as the copper content rises. The three well-resolved peaks represented by (100), (110), and (200) indicate a hexagonal mesoporous silica structure (p6mm) [32]. At copper loadings exceeding 20%, the small (110) and (200) diffraction peaks disappear, and the strong (100) peak becomes weaker and indistinct. These changes in the small-angle XRD patterns also prove the destroyed or blocked silicate frameworks as a result of the excess copper content, which can be also observed in the TEM images. The physicochemical properties of the samples with different copper loadings are summarized in Table 1. The large specific surface area (A BET) of the SBA-15 (∼732 m2/g) is advantageous for its use as a support for the copper-based catalyst, since a large A BET plays an important role in the catalyst activity. After the introduction of copper, the Cu/SBA-15 samples show decreased A BET values relative to the SBA-15. However, the Cu/SBA-15 samples possess larger A BET values at lower copper loadings (10Cu/SBA-15 and 15Cu/SBA-15) compared to the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. When the copper loading in the Cu/SBA-15 is increased to 20%, the A BET falls below that of Cu/SiO2. These observations indicate that the proper copper loading on the SBA-15 is crucial to the structure and activity of the Cu/SBA-15 catalyst. Also, the copper particle size (dCu ) gradually increases from 10.2 nm in 10Cu/SBA-15 to 18.4 nm in 25Cu/SBA-15, which indicates that a low copper loading can contribute to a small particle size and, accordingly, better copper dispersion in the catalyst. Moreover, all the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts exhibit significantly lower copper particle sizes compared to the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, suggesting their better activities. The lower A BET and larger dCu values suggest that the copper sites become embedded within the framework instead of on the surface. Thus, a decrease in the copper dispersion from 15.4% to 7.1% is detected as the copper loading increases. In general, the 10Cu/SBA-15 and 15Cu/SBA-15 samples exhibit smaller particle sizes and well-ordered tubular structures, but 20Cu/SBA-15 and 25Cu/SBA-15 samples possess larger particle sizes and destroyed frameworks. Thus, framework collapse leads to lower specific surface areas and copper dispersion, which inevitably depresses the number of active sites in contact with the DEM and hydrogen and induces severe internal diffusion during the reduction and catalytic processes. To eliminate internal diffusion and provide adequate active sites, we believe that the copper loading on the SBA-15 should not exceed 20%. 3.3 Chemical states of surface species H2-TPR was applied to characterize the reducibility of the calcined catalysts and obtain additional information about surface speciation. The H2-TPR profiles of the calcined samples with different copper loadings are shown in Fig. 5 . Each sample presents different reduction performance profiles and accordingly overlapped peaks. In Fig. 5, all samples present overlapped peaks with gaps of 10–30 K. The 10Cu/SBA-15 and 15Cu/SBA-15 samples exhibit peaks at lower temperature (∼450–475 K), which is mainly ascribed to their small particle size with good reducibility. In addition, the samples with larger particle size, including the 15Cu/SiO2 and 25Cu/SBA-15 catalysts, tend to require higher temperatures for reduction (∼500 K) due to their poor reducibility. Because copper phyllosilicate tends to be reduced at a higher temperature than well-dispersed CuO, the broader asymmetric and shoulder peaks in the 10Cu/SBA-15, 15Cu/SBA-15, and 20Cu/SBA-15 catalysts could be attributed to the reduction of the well-dispersed CuO and copper phyllosilicate [44–46]. The different reducibilities of the copper species coexisting on the SBA-15 surface, as shown in the TPR profiles (see Fig. 5), may lead to slower reduction (sometimes explained by a double reduction process: Cu2+ → Cu+ → Cu°) [47]. This may favor the formation of more Cu+ species after activation of the calcined catalyst. However, the 15Cu/SiO2 and 25Cu/SBA-15 catalysts show narrow, nearly symmetric peaks at a higher reduction temperature, which may be because the larger, poorly dispersed CuO particles need this higher reduction temperature, and generate closer, overlapped, and less asymmetric peaks [44]. The narrow peak means similar reducibility and may reflect the direct reduction of Cu2+ to Cu° [29,48], which may lead to a lower Cu+ content. The Cu 2p XPS spectra of all the samples are illustrated in Fig. 6 A. Obviously, two strong narrow peaks are observed at 932.2 and 952.2 eV, corresponding to the Cu° and/or Cu+ species. However, no obvious peak occurs near 943 eV, indicating that the Cu2+ species are reduced to Cu+ or Cu° species, in good agreement with the XRD results. However, small shoulder peaks due to Cu2+ are detected at 935.5 eV in the 25Cu/SBA-15 and 20Cu/SBA-15 samples, which implies a minor amount of residual Cu2+ species with poor reducibility. These may result because the highly copper-loaded samples with relatively large particle sizes and more copper phyllosilicate need a higher temperature to reduce, consistent with the FT-IR and H2-TPR results [49]. In fact, both the Cu° and Cu+ species are active sites in the ester hydrogenation process, but share similar binding energy values. To identify the precise chemical states of the metal, Cu LMM Auger spectra were obtained. The kinetic energies of the reduced samples are presented in Fig. 6B. All samples exhibit pairs of overlapping kinetic energy peaks at the center of ∼916 and 913 eV, corresponding to Cu° and Cu+, respectively. The specific ratios of Cu+/Cu° were calculated and are listed in Fig. 6B. Clearly, Cu+ and Cu° species coexist on the surface of the SBA-15 support. The Cu+/Cu° ratio rises to a maximum at 1.31 in the 15Cu/SBA-15 sample, and then drops to 0.96 for the 25Cu/SBA-14 catalyst. The variable Cu+/Cu° ratios arise from the different particle sizes and copper species with different reducibilities that coexist on the calcined catalysts, which agrees well with the XRD and H2-TPR results. In addition, it is believed that a higher Cu+/Cu° ratio should contribute to better selectivity in the ester hydrogenation process [50,51]. Thus, combining the foregoing characterization results, we can safely say that the 15Cu/SBA-15 sample would show a better catalytic performance in the DEM hydrogenation process. 3.4 Catalyst performance It is well accepted that the hydrogenation of DEM is a two-step reaction process that includes DEM hydrogenation to HPE and HPE hydrogenation to 1,3-PDO, as depicted in Scheme 1 [52]. However, side reactions can lead to the over-hydrogenation of HPE and 1,3-PDO to ethyl propanoate (EP) and n-propanol (NP), respectively, making it relatively low selectivity to 1,3-PDO with a relatively short lifetime [10,12]. These problems would significantly limit the hydrogenation process on industrial scale. To ascertain the intrinsic activity of the catalyst, turnover frequency (TOF) numbers for the Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/SiO2 catalysts were calculated based on their dispersion, Cu LMM Auger spectra, (The Cu LMM Auger spectra of 15Cu/SiO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. S1) and reaction rates when the DEM conversion was less than 25%, as listed in Table 2 [38,53]. The TOF values for the Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/SiO2 catalysts rise from 2.3 to 3.4 h−1, respectively, and then drop to 2.1 h−1 with increasing copper loading. The 15Cu/SBA-15 sample exhibits the highest TOF value, and thus, excellent intrinsic activity. The Cu LMM Auger spectra showed that the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts with different copper loadings had variable Cu+/Cu° ratios, which reached a maximum at 1.31 in the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst. Therefore, despite the synergetic actions of the Cu° and Cu+ species in the ester hydrogenation process, the volcano-like trend of the TOF, like the Cu+/Cu° ratio, suggests that Cu+ may perform the more important catalytic role. In fact, the Cu+ sites act to adsorb and activate CO groups, while the Cu° sites act to adsorb and activate H2 molecules [54]. Given the positive relationship for TOF as function of Cu+/Cu°, we are convinced that carbonyl adsorption or activation by Cu+ is rate-determining for the hydrogenation process, which has also been confirmed by several kinetics reports [50]. The TOF number reflects the intrinsic activity of a catalyst and is related to the chemical state of the active site. A high Cu+/Cu° ratio is indicative of a high TOF value, but does not ensure a high Cu+ species surface area. The activity of a catalyst is also related to the support’s specific surface area, because a poor A BET value is often accompanied by diffusion effects and, more importantly, encapsulated active sites. In contrast, a larger A BET enables better dispersion rather than burial of the active sites. Owing to the large A BET for SBA-15, the XRD and N2O titration results indicated smaller particle sizes with higher dispersions of copper metal in the Cu/SBA-15 samples, which could ensure a larger number of exposed copper sites, and thus, a larger copper surface area, to efficiently adsorb and activate DEM and H2. Since the TOF calculations showed the dominant role of the Cu+ species, the Cu+ surface area and yields as a function of the copper loading are in Fig. 7 . Clearly, the differences between the Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/SiO2 arise from the different support morphologies, as seen in the TEM images in Fig. 3. Compared to the 15Cu/SiO2 catalyst with a dispersion of 6.5%, the tubular well-ordered 15Cu/SBA-15 has a larger specific surface area (444 m2/g) and higher copper site dispersion (12.5%), as shown in Table 1. Furthermore, the Cu+/Cu° ratio also rises to 1.31 in the 15Cu/SBA-15 sample, as shown in the Cu LMM Auger spectra result in Fig. 6B, which also leads to a higher TOF value. These advantages result in a larger active surface area, especially in terms of Cu+ species (14.1 m2/g). Thus, the wide difference in the yields of 1,3-PDO and HPE between Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/SiO2 is a result of the Cu+ species surface area, as shown in Fig. 7. Additional evidence may be found in the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts with different copper loadings. Despite the fact that 20Cu/SBA-15 contains twice as much copper as 10Cu/SBA-15, the former, with a partially collapsed framework, has a dispersion of only 9.2% compared to the latter catalyst at 15.4%. Furthermore, although the 10Cu/SBA-15 catalyst shares a similar Cu+/Cu° ratio with the 20Cu/SBA-15 catalyst (see Fig. 6A), this results in only a small increase in the Cu+ surface area, and thus, similar yields of 1,3-PDO and HPE between the 10Cu/SBA-15 and 20Cu/SBA-15 samples are obtained (Fig. 7). These observations indicate that the ratio of Cu+/Cu° contributes to a higher intrinsic activity (TOF), and the well-ordered tubular structure with its high specific surface area can lead to a large number of surface active sites (especially, Cu+ species’ surface area), and thus, high yields of the 1,3-PDO and HPE products. The effects of the temperature, pressure, LHSV, and H2/DEM molar ratio on the DEM hydrogenation reaction are shown in Fig. 8 . From Fig. 8A, the conversion of DEM and selectivity for side products (NP and EP) clearly increase with temperature, while the selectivity for 1,3-PDO shows an initial increase and then declines. Thus, a relatively high temperature (over 473 K) leads to higher selectivity for side products that result from the over-hydrogenation of –OH groups in the 1,3-PDO and HPE to form NP and EP, which was also observed in the DMO hydrogenation process [44,55]. Additionally, it should be noted that traces of ethyl formate and methane are detected at temperatures above 473 K, which may stem from DEM decomposition. These results confirm that high temperatures reduce selectivity for 1,3-PDO. Fortunately, compared to the 15Cu/SiO2 sample, the 15Cu/SBA-15 sample, with its larger surface copper area and higher activity, enables the reaction to proceed at a milder temperature (∼453 K), effectively suppressing side-product formation via HPE and 1,3-PDO over-hydrogenation and DEM decomposition. In Fig. 8B and C, volcanic-trend curves for 1,3-PDO selectivity as a function of LHSV and H2/DEM mole ratio are observed; these reflect that the DEM hydrogenation process includes several successive reactions. Thus, a rational LHSV and H2/DEM mole ratio can result in higher 1,3-PDO selectivity. Finally, the pressure has a remarkable effect on selectivity for the 1,3-PDO and HPE products, but no obvious effect on the selectivity for side products. Accordingly, a higher pressure is favored to improve the 1,3-PDO selectivity. Therefore, the optimal reaction conditions are obtained as follows: 453 K, 0.6 h−1, 380 mol ratio of H2/DEM, and 5 MPa. Under the optimized conditions, the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst demonstrates the highest DEM conversion of 95% and 1,3-PDO selectivity of 61%, and outperforms the previous studies that used Cu/SiO2 as catalyst. For example, Ding et al. achieved a DEM conversion of 90.7% and 1,3-PDO selectivity of 32.3%. Similarly, Zheng et al. achieved 97% ester conversion and 43% 1,3-PDO selectivity [10,12]. Thus, we can conclude that the use of SBA-15 as a support for the copper-based catalyst can dramatically improve the activity and selectivity for 1,3-PDO in the DEM hydrogenation process. 3.5 Catalyst stability Because catalyst stability plays a key role in the practical application of a typical catalytic process, the lifetime of the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst was assessed in the DEM hydrogenation process (Fig. 9 ). In general, Cu sintering induced by thermal surface mass transfers, structural collapse, or erosion of the copper-based catalyst is believed to be the main reason for catalyst deactivation [56]. Furthermore, in ester hydrogenation reactions, a decrease in the copper surface area and the aggregation of copper particles contribute greatly to the deactivation of copper-based catalysts [57]. For example, the amorphous Cu/SiO2 catalyst is known to lose its activity within dozens of hours: Zheng et al. reported that this catalyst maintained its activity and selectivity for the first 45 h, but suddenly lost activity in a short time [54]. In He et al.’s work, the Cu/SiO2 catalyst only remained stable within 30 h [55]. These drawbacks were ascribed to the amorphous structure of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst with its lower activity, which necessitates performing the ester hydrogenation reaction at a higher temperature (over 473 K) and higher copper loading (over 20%). Unfortunately, the higher reaction temperature and copper metal loading can easily result in copper-site transmigration and assembly. Hence, the Cu/SiO2 catalyst tends to easily lose its copper surface area and thus deactivates rapidly. Owing to the structural advantages of the SBA-15, the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst is highly active due to the good copper dispersion, large specific surface area, and appropriate Cu+/Cu° ratio, which are promising features for resisting deactivation. Specifically, from Fig. 9, it is clear that the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst exhibits stable catalytic activity for the DEM hydrogenation reaction for as long as 180 h. Furthermore, there is almost no obvious change in its catalytic activity after 180 h, which is significantly longer than the conventional Cu/SiO2 catalyst. This observation also confirms the structural advantages of the SBA-15 as a support for the copper-based catalyst. In addition, according to previous studies, the conventionally used Cu/SiO2 catalyst tends to lose its specific surface area dramatically, decreasing from about 350 to 150 m2/g [44,58]. However, owing to the thermally stable SBA-15 framework, after a 180-h run, the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst still maintains a tubular channel structure as regular as the fresh catalyst, (Fig. 10 ). Furthermore, no obvious change in the specific surface area is observed, as shown in Table S5 in the Supporting Information. Moreover, comparisons of the XRD and Cu LMM Auger spectra between the fresh and used 15Cu/SBA-15 (see Fig. S2) indicate that the copper particle size only increases from 11.3 to 16.5 nm, and the Cu+/Cu° ratio decreases slightly from 1.31 to 1.20, which suggests that the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst retains strong activity for DEM hydrogenation after 180 h. Therefore, it can be concluded that the tubular channel structure of the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst is effectively resistant to deactivation over 180 h. Furthermore, we can safely say that the mesoporous Cu/SBA-15 catalyst shows significantly better catalytic performance, with a DEM conversion of up to 95%, 1,3-PDO selectivity up to 61%, and catalyst lifetime exceeding 180 h, compared to the conventional catalysts applied in the hydrogenation of DEM. We believe that the mesoporous Cu/SBA-15 catalyst will be very promising and important for optimizing the process of DEM hydrogenation to obtain higher conversions, better 1,3-PDO selectivities, and longer catalyst lifetimes; that is, Cu/SBA-15 will be a potential catalyst for the industrial hydrogenation of DEM, which is of great significance. 4 Conclusions SBA-15 has a large specific surface area and well-ordered tubular channel structure. These attractive features suggested SBA-15 as a support for the synthesis of Cu/SBA-15 catalysts via the ammonia evaporation method. Their superior catalytic performance in DEM hydrogenation was revealed by N2-physisorption, XRD, ICP-AES, N2O titration, TEM, H2-TPR, FT-IR, and XPS studies. Compared to conventional amorphous Cu/SiO2 catalysts, the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts exhibit well-ordered tubular channel structures, better copper metal dispersion, and rational Cu+/Cu° ratios, affording higher TOFs and copper species surface areas, and thus, good activity and 1,3-PDO selectivity in DEM hydrogenation. Under the optimized conditions, a DEM conversion of 95% and 1,3-PDO selectivity of 61% were achieved. Furthermore, the 15Cu/SBA-15 catalyst demonstrated a long lifetime, exceeding 180 h. These results advance DEM hydrogenation a promising method for producing 1,3-PDO. coredata.dc:description: SBA-15 is considered as an ideal support to ensure a copper-based catalyst with high activity and selectivity. In this work, the hydrogenation of diethyl malonate (DEM) to 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO) over Cu/SBA-15 catalysts was investigated. Compared to the conventional Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the Cu/SBA-15 catalysts exhibited higher DEM conversions (up to 95%), better 1,3-PDO selectivities (up to 61%), and longer lifetime (over 180 h). These improvements were ascribed to the well-ordered tubular channel structure, better copper active-site dispersion, and appropriate Cu+/Cu° ratio in the Cu/SBA-15, affording higher TOFs and copper species surface areas, which was confirmed by N2-physisorption, X-ray diffraction, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy, N2O titration, transmission electron microscopy, H2 temperature-programmed reduction, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyses. The Cu/SBA-15 in this work advances the prospects of DEM hydrogenation as a promising method to produce 1,3-PDO on industrial scale.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement of diethyl malonate hydrogenation to 1,3-propanediol using mesoporous Cu/SBA-15 as catalyst
